snippet: The agency has put software in thousands of computers that allows for surveillance and can also create a path for launching cyberattacks, according to documents, experts and officials.
abstract: National Security Agency has implanted software in nearly 100,000 computers around the world that allows United States to conduct surveillance on those machines and can also create a digital highway for launching cyberattacks; program, code-named Quantum, uses secret radio frequency technology that enables it to enter and alter data in computers even if they are not connected to the Internet.

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and THOM SHANKER

lead_paragraph: The agency has put software in thousands of computers that allows for surveillance and can also create a path for launching cyberattacks, according to documents, experts and officials.

headline.main: N.S.A. Devises Radio Pathway Into Computers
headline.print_headline: N.S.A. Devises Radio Pathway Into Computers
